contentrichtext.text: '''''Yellow Arrow''''' is a public art project that was active from 2004-2006 and was created by Christopher Allen, [[Brian House]], and [[Jesse Shapins]], collectively known as Counts Media. The project is an important example of [[locative media]] and mobile phone art and draws concepts from [[psychogeography]]. ''Yellow Arrow'' stickers are obtained from the project website<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/01/AR2005070102280.html |title=Targeting the 'Art' Around Every Corner |publisher=washingtonpost.com |date= 2005-07-02|accessdate=2011-04-10 |first=Tommy |last=Nguyen}}</ref> and placed anywhere in the public realm. When encountering a sticker on the street, one can send the unique code printed on it as a [[short message service|text message]] to the project phone number. Moments later a message will be received that was left by the person who placed the sticker. The ''Yellow Arrow'' symbol means "thereâ€™s more here: a hidden detail, a funny story, a memory, and a crazy experience." Each arrow links digital content to a specific location using the mobile phone.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/25/technology/techspecial2/25geo.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=%22yellow%20arrow%22&st=cse | work=The New York Times | first=Ethan | last=Todras-Whitehill | title=Making Connections, Here and Now | date=2006-01-25}}</ref> As an underground phenomenon, the project developed an international community, and 7535 ''Yellow Arrow'' stickers were placed in 467 cities and 35 countries.<ref>{{cite web|last=House|first=Brian|title=Yellow Arrow|url=http://brianhouse.net/works/yellow_arrow/|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref> Since first appearing at the [[Psy-Geo-Conflux]] in New York in May 2004, ''Yellow Arrow'' has been featured in The New York Times, Wired,<ref>{{cite news|last=Howe|first=Jeff|title=Text in the City|url=http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/12.09/play.html?pg=3|accessdate=14 September 2012|newspaper=Wired|date=September 2004}}</ref> Newsweek, The Washington Post,<ref>{{cite news|last=Nguyen|first=Tommy|title=Targeting the 'Art' Around Every Corner|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/01/AR2005070102280.html|accessdate=14 September 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=2005-07-02}}</ref> The Boston Globe, CNN and NBC, the London Times, Politiken,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://politiken.dk/kultur/fakta_kultur/ECE115054/yellow-arrow---et-globalt-kunstprojekt/|accessdate=14 September 2012|newspaper=Politiken|date=2005-06-06}}</ref> Liberation, Diari de Barcelona, and de Volkskrant. ''Yellow Arrow'' was also featured in Lonely Planet's Guide to Experimental Travel. In ''Toward the Sentient City'', Mark Shepard writes, "In place of the ubiquitous bronze plaque providing "official narratives" affixed to the side of "significant" urban structures or spaces, ''Yellow Arrow'' provides for the unofficial annotation of everyday urban places by ordinary citizens."<ref>{{cite book|last=Shepard|first=Mark|title=Sentient City|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51586-3|pages=28}}</ref> ''Yellow Arrow'' was included in the exhibition ''Design and the Elastic Mind'' at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York City in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=MoMA.org {{!}} Design and The Elastic Mind|url=http://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2008/elasticmind/|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref> In 2006, the project was discontinued and its content was archived on [[Flickr]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.yellowarrow.net Yellow Arrow website] *[http://www.flickr.com/photos/yellowarrow/collections/ Yellow Arrow archive on flickr] [[Category:Artist groups and collectives]] [[Category:Hypertext]] [[Category:Stickers]] {{art-org-stub}}
